entry.title: Pivotal CloudFoundry has more tires than any normal human should have to kick
entry.summary: One of the biggest and best brains in the container community tried to get started with PCF. for about 10 minutes.
entry.content:
Kelsey Hightower, one of the best advocates and biggest brains in the container community, decided yesterday was the day to dig in to links::Pivotal Cloud Foundry.

Today will be the day I finally kick the tires on Pivotal Cloud Foundry. https://t.co/q6z4Gm4Sue

— Kelsey Hightower (@kelseyhightower) July 25, 2017

That desire lasted just under half an hour.

Or not: Installing PCF requires at least 10 concurrent instances for testing and typically at least 30 for production deployments. https://t.co/hGwwAK2AtO

— Kelsey Hightower (@kelseyhightower) July 25, 2017

Why? To get started with PCF, you need at least 30 systems available. FOR ITS CONTROL PLANE ALONE.

That's straight from the documentation. Why are 30 machines required for a production deployment? https://t.co/LtH7iSqx8k

— Kelsey Hightower (@kelseyhightower) July 25, 2017

@Pivotal, seriously. If it takes you 30 VMs to deploy your first container, how are you helping people deliver better software faster? Hint: it doesn’t.

entry.title: The Truth is Out There
entry.content:
We are going to do our best to find it and bring it to light

But it’s increasingly hard to find. The (fools?) gold rush that is the ever-growing Linux container industry is so full of marketing double-speak that true information is hard to find.

That is what we are going to do our best to broadcast from this base station.

The truth about what conatiners are, what they can do, and how we can all take advantage of them. Some of the content will be home grown. Most of it will likely be found art. Sometimes we will have to knock down FUD when we see it.
